hints.content:
Does $\blueD{(9 \times 3) \times 3}=\greenD{9 \times (3 \times 3)}?$

Yes! When multiplying, we can group numbers differently by moving the parentheses and still arrive at the same answer. [[☃ explanation 1]]

This is called the **associative property of multiplication**.

options.showPrompt: Don't believe us? Check this out.

hints.content:
Does $\blueD{(9 \times 3) \times 3}=\maroonD{27 + 3}?$

$
\begin{align}
\blueD{(9 \times 3) \times 3} &\stackrel{?}{=}  \maroonD{27 +  3} \\\\
\blueD{27 \times 3} &\neq  \maroonD{27 +3}
 \end{align}$

No, $\blueD{(9 \times 3) \times 3}$ is not equivalent to $\maroonD{27 +3}$.

The following expressions are equivalent to $\blueD{(9 \times 3) \times 3}$:

* $\greenD{9 \times (3 \times 3)}$

* $\purpleC{9 \times 9}$

question.content:
**Which two expressions are equivalent to ${(9 \times 3) \times 3}$ ?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
